required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Repository for Sepsis and Postresuscitation Samples
clinical_study.official_title: Repository for Samples Collected From Sepsis and Postresuscitation Patients in Emergency Intensive Care Unit

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to find a new therapeutic strategy by investigating the serial serum samples of patients with sepsis or postresuscitation state.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

secondary_outcome.time_frame: until hospital discharge, an expected average of 2 weeks
Until ward transfer or discharge, an expected average of 7 days
at discharge, an expected average of 2 weeks and at 6-month
secondary_outcome.description: Favorable neurologic outcome is used for outcome measure in postresuscitation patients only. Favorable neurologic outcome means cerebral performance category 1 and 2. This outcome is measured at discharge and 6-month after admission.

arm_group.description: Adults (age over 16 years old) who have survived from nontraumatic cardiac arrest and admitted to ICU.
Adults (age over 16 years old) who satisfy the sepsis criteria (SIRS>=2 and infection is suspected for a cause) and admitted to the ICU.

biospec_descr.textblock: Patients sera at ICU admission, day-1, day-3 and day-7 are stored in deep freezer.

study_pop.textblock: Sepsis patients admitted to ICU Postresuscitation patients admitted to ICU

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age over 16 years old
- Admitted to ICU
- Diagnosed as having sepsis or as postresuscitation status
- Definition of sepsis: 2 or more SIRS criteria + infection is suspected
- Definition of postresuscitation status: Survived from non-traumatic cardiac arrest
Exclusion Criteria:
- refusal to participate
- DNAR status

reference.citation: Angus DC, Linde-Zwirble WT, Lidicker J, Clermont G, Carcillo J, Pinsky MR. Epidemiology of severe sepsis in the United States: analysis of incidence, outcome, and associated costs of care. Crit Care Med. 2001 Jul;29(7):1303-10.

Dombrovskiy VY, Martin AA, Sunderram J, Paz HL. Rapid increase in hospitalization and mortality rates for severe sepsis in the United States: a trend analysis from 1993 to 2003. Crit Care Med. 2007 May;35(5):1244-50.
Cohen J. The immunopathogenesis of sepsis. Nature. 2002 Dec 19-26;420(6917):885-91. Review.
